DOC.HEAD: Pope Expresses `Deep Pain' Over Violence in Romania
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Wednesday joined the condemnation of brutal repression of protesters in Romania, and prominent Britons demanded that hard-line President Nicolae Ceausescu be stripped of a knighthood that was bestowed on him. ``With deep pain we have all heard the news of dead and wounded in some Romanian cities,'' the pope said. His comment on the violence, in which up thousands may have been killed, came at the end of his regular weekly audience. John Paul said he was praying that human rights and religious liberty would prevail in Romania, which is controlled by the last Stalinist regime in the Soviet bloc. Ceausescu, who has ruled Romania for 24 years, was given the Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath, the highest honor for a foreign leader, during a state visit in June 1978. Lord Bethell, vice-chairman of the European Parliament's human rights subcommittee, said ``the Order of the Bloodbath would have been more appropriate.'' In Geneva, leaders of the World Council of Churches and affiliated organizations expressed shock at the crackdown and said it revealed the ``ruthlessness'' of Romania's leadership. ``It is with shock and deep sorrow that we have learned of the tragedy in Timisoara where violent repression by the armed forces took the lives of many people,'' a statement said. Most of the violence, which began last weekend, has occurred in Timisoara, a city in western Romania. In Bulgaria, where the Communist leadership was equally rigid until last month, several thousand people gathered outside the Romanian Embassy in Sofia, shouting ``Ceausescu is a shame for Europe!'' ``Fascists!'' and ``Murderers!'' The embassy refused to accept a protest letter. The independent Union of Democratic Forces, which organized the rally, urged Bulgaria to ``dissolve all treaties'' with the Romanian regime and recall the Bulgarian ambassador. The two nations are allies in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. President Francesco Cossiga of Italy made his feelings clear during his annual Christmas meeting with diplomats, telling the Romanian ambassador, Constantin Tudor: ``I was hoping this meeting would take place in a different atmosphere. We are very saddened and worried ... about what is happening in Romania.'' In Brussels, NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said the 16 nations of the Western alliance expressed ``their dismay at the serious loss of life.'' ``The government's use of massive brutal force to suppress these demonstrations illustrates that the Romanian regime does not rule with the consent of the people,'' he said. At the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in Vienna on Wednesday, Romanian representatives were isolated. Delegates condemned the killing, but the Romanians managed to prevent the observance of a minute of silence. Austria, as host, declared to the conference that ``the Romanian regime of murderers will be unable to stay in power.'' Martin Vukovich, leader of the Austrian delegation, said all delegations condemned the events in Romania, but that the Soviet condemnation was restrained. The Soviets urged their Romanian allies to heed the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreements on European security and cooperation, he said. In Yugoslavia, the Communist Party leadership decided to ``stop concrete cooperation with the Romanian Communist Party for the time being.'' A statement from the party presidency held the Romanian party responsible ``for last weekend's tragic events and their consequences,'' the official news agency Tanjug reported, and an invitation to Romania to send a delegation to the Yugoslav party congress scheduled for January was withdrawn. Hungary gave a note to Romanian Ambassador Traian Pop that condemned ``the brutal crackdown on peaceful demonstrators.'' Legislators observed a minute of silence for the victims and voted to drape the parliament building in black. Czechoslovakia's parliament condemned the crackdown and said the government in Prague should ``draw the necessary conclusions'' from the events. There was no elaboration. The Foreign Ministry in Czechoslovakia, where the beating of protesters started an uprising that ended the Communist Party power monopoly in less than a month, protesting the use of force on demonstrators. Czechoslovak air controllers have urged an international boycott of Romanian plans. Eugene Ionesco, the celebrated Romanian-born playwright, said the Soviet Union should help arrange the downfall of Ceausescu, the French newspaper Le Figaro reported. Ionesco, who lives in Paris, said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``alone can do something, because Romania is literally colonized by the Soviet Union,'' the newspaper reported.
